author: By Zach Montague
title: Biden Says He Is Considering Seeking a Gas Tax Holiday
description: With regular gasoline around $5 per gallon, suspending the federal gas tax would provide a measure of relief for consumers, but Congress would need to take action.
content: REHOBOTH BEACH, Del. — President Biden said on Monday that he was considering seeking a gas tax holiday to ease high fuel prices, a major political dilemma for the White House as it struggles to address record inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Opinion Desk
title: Did You Start Therapy Recently?
description: Times Opinion would like to hear from you.
content: An “epidemic” of loneliness. Prolonged grief. Rising levels of anxiety and depression. And that feeling you didn’t have a name for — languishing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: ‘The Senate Needs a Soul’
description: Senator Raphael Warnock discusses the Jan. 6 hearings, Georgia politics and his history-making journey to the Senate.
content: Raphael Warnock claims he’s not a politician, though he certainly sounds like one and serves as one. The U.S. senator from Georgia, who has long been the pastor at Martin Luther King Jr.’s former church, says that his “entry into politics is an extension” of his work on a range of what he sees as moral issues, such as health care, criminal-justice reform and voting rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Dutch Government Activates ‘Early Warning’ Because of Russian Cutbacks on Gas
description: The government will allow more burning of coal to generate electricity as gas supplies tighten.
content: The Dutch government said on Monday that Russia’s tightening of gas supplies to Europe had prompted it to declare an “early warning” stage of a natural gas crisis, a move that will allow more electric power to be generated by burning coal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan
title: Failed Autopsies, False Arrests: A Risk of Bias in Death Examinations
description: Disastrous errors by medical examiners have raised questions about whether they are influenced by prejudgments and a close relationship with the police.
content: Emberly McLean-Bernard, born six weeks premature in rural Mississippi, weighed less than five pounds when doctors sent her home. She did not cry and barely ate, her mother said, and not two days elapsed before she began to gasp for breath. Jocelyn McLean rushed her daughter to the nearest emergency room, but the baby was already turning blue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Russia’s blockade of Ukraine’s food exports is a ‘war crime,’ says the E.U.’s foreign policy chief.
description: The war is contributing to global food shortages and rising prices, and the United Nations warns of possible famine. Ukraine is usually a major grain exporter.
content: The Black Sea blockade that is preventing Ukraine from exporting food and other goods is a “war crime” and Russia will be held accountable if it continues, the European Union’s foreign policy chief, Josep Borrell Fontelles, said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Andrew Higgins, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Rick Gladstone
title: Russia’s Blockade of Ukraine Is ‘War Crime,’ Top E.U. Official Says
description: The remarks by the official, Josep Borrell Fontelles, were among the strongest language from a Western leader in describing the Kremlin’s tactics to subjugate Ukraine.
content: LONDON — The Russian blockade that has stopped Ukraine from exporting its vast storehouses of grain and other goods, threatening starvation in distant corners of the globe, is a “war crime,” the European Union’s top foreign policy official declared Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Juneteenth Reminds Us to Think About Economic Freedom, Not Just Legal Liberty
description: Who is fully free, who is partially free and who is not free at all?
content: For African Americans, the end of legalized slavery in the United States was the beginning of freedom — but only the beginning. The incompleteness of their liberation is clear in the proclamation by a Union general in Galveston, Texas, on June 19, 1865, which is remembered on America’s newest federal holiday, Juneteenth National Independence Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.9 Million Homes in California
description: A modern farmhouse in Los Angeles, a Spanish-style home in Kensington and a midcentury-modern retreat in Palm Springs.
content: This house sits on a large corner lot in the Sherman Oaks neighborhood, just south of Magnolia Boulevard, the San Fernando Valley thoroughfare that runs east into Burbank. It is in a quiet, residential area less than a five-minute drive from Louis Armstrong Middle School, a public school for students in sixth through eighth grades. Westfield Fashion Square, a popular shopping mall, is also about five minutes away, and the shopping and dining on Ventura Boulevard is just over a mile away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michio Kaku
title: In a Parallel Universe, Another You
description: As they probe the secrets of the cosmos, scientists question whether our reality is but one in a multiverse.
content: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What is reality? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Gustavo Petro Wins the Election, Becoming Colombia’s First Leftist Leader
description: The former rebel and longtime senator’s victory sets the third largest nation in Latin America on a sharply new path.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — For the first time, Colombia will have a leftist president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: The Stanley Cup Finals and ‘Chernobyl: The Lost Tapes’
description: The Tampa Bay Lightning battles the Colorado Avalanche for the Stanley Cup. And HBO airs a new documentary about the Chernobyl disaster.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, June 20-26. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: In Ad, Shotgun-Toting Greitens Asks Voters to Go ‘RINO Hunting’
description: A right-wing Senate candidate accompanies a squad of heavily armed men as they storm a home looking for ‘Republicans in name only.’
content: Eric Greitens, a Republican candidate for the United States Senate in Missouri, released a violent new political advertisement on Monday showing himself racking a shotgun and accompanying a team of men armed with assault rifles as they stormed — SWAT team-style — into a home in search of “RINOs,” or Republicans in name only.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: With Roe Set to End, Many Women Worry About High-Risk Pregnancies
description: Most states likely to outlaw abortions allow for exceptions to save a mother’s life. But many women and doctors ask: Where will lawmakers draw the line?
content: PHOENIX — Brianna was seven weeks pregnant when she started worrying she would not live to see her due date. She had a narrow windpipe severely scarred by surgeries she had undergone as an infant, and as her pregnancy developed, she began wheezing and straining for breath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Yong
title: How Animals See Themselves
description: The most familiar of settings can feel newly unfamiliar through the senses of other creatures.
content: Spectacle floods into my eyes whenever I watch a wildlife documentary. A vortex of small fish is gradually picked off by waves of oceanic predators. Snakes chase after marine iguanas. Giraffes clash at sunset.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin McCann
title: Parts of Yellowstone Will Reopen This Week After Damaging Floods
description: The National Park Service also said it would spend $50 million on repairs that would restore access to about 80 percent of the park within two weeks.
content: Parts of Yellowstone National Park will reopen to a limited number of visitors on Wednesday, and the National Park Service will spend $50 million to fast-track repair work to restore access to about 80 percent of the park within two weeks, officials said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: He Saw. He Believed. Now He Can Be an N.B.A. Star.
description: The former Duke center Mark Williams is expected to be picked at the N.B.A. draft this week. He’s quickly learning what going pro really means.
content: MIAMI — The training drill is named after LeBron James. Most people would be better off if they just let him do it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Washington Might Be About to Do Something Right for America’s Wildlife
description: An “unthinkable level of bipartisan support” may just lead to a win for species in peril.
content: NASHVILLE — The media hasn’t paid much attention to the Recovering America’s Wildlife Act. With a war raging in Ukraine, a domestic economy in tumult, an attempted coup being explicated on national television, a virus that keeps evolving and a devastating heat wave enveloping parts of the United States and Europe, that’s not surprising. But this landmark legislation, known in conservation circles as RAWA, is poised to become the single most effective tool in combatting biodiversity loss since the Endangered Species Act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Grenfell Tower Still Stands. So Do Questions About What to Do With It.
description: Five years ago a fast-moving blaze in the London high-rise left 72 people dead and the building a shell. Some want to see it torn down, but others feel it should remain.
content: LONDON — The blackened walls of Grenfell Tower, wrapped in white plastic, still cast their shadow over the surrounding neighborhood in West London, five years after the fire that killed 72 people. What to do with the 220-foot structure — or what to build in its place — is one of the tragedy’s many unresolved issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Haramis
title: The Man Behind Fashion’s Most Famous Bob
description: Being Anna Wintour’s hairstylist may sound glamorous, but it’s his art practice that gets Andreas Anastasis talking.
content: For the past six years, at 8 a.m. sharp, Andreas Anastasis has walked to Anna Wintour’s Greenwich Village townhouse, where for about 20 minutes every weekday he maintains upkeep, whether it’s cutting, coloring, spraying, blow-drying or styling, of the most instantly recognizable bob in fashion — maybe the world. A short distance from there, “right across the street from Carrie Bradshaw’s house,” he has spent nearly a decade running his namesake salon, where he now works two days a week. The only magazine in the waiting area is Vogue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: ‘We Are Not Safe’: Ethiopians Flee Massacre that Killed Hundreds
description: The massacre in Oromia, the nation’s largest region, came as the country grappled with a grueling civil war and the worst drought in decades.
content: KIGALI, Rwanda — For decades, the village had been a sanctuary for the families, who tilled the land and cared for their herds in Ethiopia’s largest region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman
title: A new brand of activist takes aim at the Ukraine war and the climate crisis, together.
description: BRUSSELS — Emmanuel Macron, the president of France, had just finished a speech at a major conference on Europe.
content: BRUSSELS — Emmanuel Macron, the president of France, had just finished a speech at a major conference on Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: ‘We Want to Know Whose Brain Is Healing and Why’
description: In a study, Dr. Jennifer Coughlin observed brain activity that may help predict the onset of trauma-related illnesses and cognitive decline. N.F.L. players are helping to further her research.
content: BALTIMORE — Jonathan Martin believes he’s doing most things right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Angier
title: The Incredible Journey of Three African Wild Dogs
description: Three sisters braved lions, crocodiles, poachers, raging rivers and other dangers on a 1,300-mile transnational effort to forge a new dynasty.
content: The three sisters knew they had to leave home. They were African wild dogs, elite predators of the sub-Saharan region and among the most endangered mammals on Earth. At 3 years old, they were in the prime of their vigor, ferocity and buoyant, pencil-limbed indifference to gravity. If they did not seize the chance to trade the security of their birth pack for new opportunities elsewhere, they might well die as they had lived: as subordinate, self-sacrificing maiden aunts with no offspring of their own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: How Paintings Lost in a Small-Town Art Heist Were Recovered 50 Years Later
description: Two sleuths — a curator and a librarian — in New Paltz, N.Y., helped the F.B.I. track down 200-year-old paintings that were stolen from a historical society in 1972.
content: On a Wednesday evening in February 1972, as police officers and emergency responders in New Paltz, N.Y., flocked to a fire, somebody snatched a pair of 19th-century portraits of a wealthy local couple from a historical society elsewhere in town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: 15-Year-Old Is Killed and 3 Are Shot in Gunfire at D.C. Music Festival
description: The police had shut down the event, known as Moechella, a free street festival that they said was unauthorized, after previous disturbances.
content: A 15-year-old boy was killed and three adults, including a police officer, were shot when gunfire erupted Sunday night at an unauthorized music event in a Washington, D.C., neighborhood known for its nightlife, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Joy Dong
title: China’s Once-Sizzling Property Market Has Started to Cool
description: New home prices in China have fallen, and would-be buyers are thinking twice. That’s bad news for the overall economy.
content: A year ago, business was humming for Liang Jiawei, a property salesman in Zhanjiang, a coastal city in southern China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Ostrovsky, Ainara Tiefenthäler and Alessandro Pavone
title: Hear the stories of Ukrainians who were forcibly resettled to Russia and escaped.
description: Since Russia invaded Ukraine in February, thousands of refugees from Ukraine have been sent to so-called filtration camps, where they have been interrogated and then forced to resettle to Russia.
content: Since Russia invaded Ukraine in February, thousands of refugees from Ukraine have been sent to so-called filtration camps, where they have been interrogated and then forced to resettle to Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: In a Town Crippled by Grief, the Healing Power of a Perfect Pitch
description: Uvalde, Texas, was set to cancel its Little League All-Star Championship after a school shooting left 21 people dead. Then, the decision was made: The games would go on.
content: UVALDE, Texas — Young people in their crisp Little League uniforms ran up and down the field in giddy anticipation. The smell of nacho cheese and sizzling chicken fajitas spread through the bleachers on the hot summer night breeze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wu and Matthew Cullen
title: A Wildfire Year
description: Three million acres have already burned in the West.
content: The American West is burning more quickly than it has in a decade. New Mexico has been fighting its two biggest wildfires on record for more than a month. About 3 million acres of U.S. land — almost the size of Connecticut — have already burned this year. And with summer starting tomorrow and a widespread heat wave already in place, the burning is likely to get worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bonnie Kristian
title: Are We Sure America Is Not at War in Ukraine?
description: If we have so far avoided calling it war, maybe that’s only because we’ve become so uncertain of the meaning of the word.
content: In the more than three months since Russia invaded Ukraine, the Biden administration has said a lot of things about the war. It had to walk a few of them back almost immediately, like when President Biden’s statement that Vladimir Putin “cannot remain in power” turned out not to be a call for regime change. On other points, its rhetoric has sharpened over time: In March, America’s goal was to help Ukraine defend itself; by the end of April it was a “weakened” Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: The Life of Jean Rhys, a Uniquely Brilliant and Thorny Writer
description: Miranda Seymour’s “I Used to Live Here Once” is a biography of the author of “Wide Sargasso Sea,” who had a talent for facing hard truths.
content: Like George Orwell, Thomas Hardy and W.H. Auden, the British novelist Jean Rhys did not want to be the subject of a biography and took steps to muddy her trail. Rhys destroyed many letters; she tore sections from journals; throughout her life she maintained, in the words of Miranda Seymour, her latest biographer, a “maddening discretion.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Chris Buckley
title: Red Flags for Forced Labor Found in China’s Car Battery Supply Chain
description: Ties to potentially coercive labor practices could prove a problem for an industry that is heavily dependent on China, once a new law barring Xinjiang products goes into effect.
content: The photograph on the mining conglomerate’s social media account showed 70 ethnic Uyghur workers standing at attention under the flag of the People’s Republic of China. It was March 2020 and the recruits would soon undergo training in management, etiquette and “loving the party and the country,” their new employer, the Xinjiang Nonferrous Metal Industry Group, announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Harlem Shooting Kills 1 and Wounds 8 Amid Violent Weekend Across the Country
description: While massacres like those in Buffalo and Uvalde are much publicized, lower-profile attacks exact a dreadful toll.
content: Just after midnight on Father’s Day, a volley of gunshots crackled around 135th Street and Harlem River Drive, violently punctuating an otherwise beautiful holiday at a popular summer picnicking area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman
title: New Brand of Activist Takes Aim at Ukraine War and Climate Crisis, Together
description: Led by young women from Eastern Europe, they are cornering Europe’s leaders and pressing them for a total energy embargo on Russia — to end the fighting and to save the planet.
content: BRUSSELS — Emmanuel Macron, the president of France, had just finished a speech at a major conference on Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Clela Rorex, Clerk Who Broke a Gay-Marriage Barrier, Dies at 78
description: In 1975 she issued a gay couple a license to marry in Colorado, becoming a hero to some and an object of hate for others.
content: Clela Rorex, who made headlines in 1975 when, as the Boulder County clerk in Colorado, she issued a marriage license to a gay couple, one of the first to do so in the nation, died on Sunday at a hospice center in Longmont, Colo. She was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zucchino and Carlotta Gall
title: 5 British Men Released by Taliban as U.K. Expresses Regret
description: Britain apologized for “any breach of Afghan culture, customs or laws” by the detainees and said their travel to Afghanistan was “a mistake.”
content: The Afghan government has released five British citizens from custody, British officials said Monday in a statement that included an apology on behalf of the men and an expression of regret from the U.K. government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tochi Onyebuchi
title: God and Horses at the Pre-Apocalypse
description: The reality of climate change is upon us, but there’s reason for hope.
content: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What is reality? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Barnard
title: Celebrating ‘Legends’ Who Catwalk Among Us
description: “Legends of Drag: Queens of a Certain Age,” a book out this month, spotlights drag elders.
content: The idea came to Harry James Hanson and Devin Antheus while both were attending “church” — their word to describe a drag show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh and Saif Hasnat
title: Ruinous Flooding in India and Bangladesh Kills at Least 116
description: In regions of the two countries still reeling from flooding in May, monsoon rains brought more misery, with hundreds of thousands of people evacuated and communications cut.
content: NEW DELHI — Heavy monsoon rains in India and Bangladesh have flooded an airport and knocked down cellphone towers, bridges and power lines, cutting off communications for millions of people and forcing the evacuation of hundreds of thousands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deirdre Mask
title: Sisters Divided by China’s Divisions
description: Zhuqing Li’s “Daughters of the Flower Fragrant Garden” tells the story of a family ripped apart by the Communist victory in China.
content: In the summer of 1949, young Chen Wenjun (“Jun”) stepped off a ferry in Jinmen, an island off the coast of southeastern China. She did not know that the Communists’ People’s Liberation Army (P.L.A.) had occupied Fuzhou, her home city, the night after she left. But in Jinmen, the anti-Communist Nationalists held their territory. None of the 9,000 P.L.A. soldiers who fought on Jinmen’s beaches made it back home. Neither did Jun, who now effectively lived in a different country from her family. Jun’s short visit to a friend quickly became a long exile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Dr. Paul M. Ellwood Jr., Architect of the H.M.O., Is Dead at 95
description: Often called the father of the health maintenance organization, he coined the term in 1970, envisioning a system that would compete for patients by providing the best care at the lowest price.
content: Dr. Paul M. Ellwood Jr., who changed the way millions of Americans receive private medical services by developing — and naming — the model for managed care known as the health maintenance organization, died on Monday in Bellingham, Wash. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Think All Viruses Get Milder With Time? Not This Rabbit-Killer.
description: The myxoma virus, fatal to millions of Australian rabbits, is a textbook example of the unexpected twists in the evolution of viruses and their hosts.
content: As the Covid death rate worldwide has fallen to its lowest level since the early weeks of the pandemic in 2020, it may be tempting to conclude that the coronavirus is becoming irreversibly milder. That notion fits with a widespread belief that all viruses start off nasty and inevitably evolve to become gentler over time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabriela Bhaskar and Abby Goodnough
title: Inside One Abortion Clinic, Signs of Nationwide Struggles
description: The Planned Parenthood clinic in Fort Myers, Fla., has seen an increase in patients arriving from Texas, even as it struggles to keep up with increasing restrictions in its own state.
content: FORT MYERS, Fla. — At a Planned Parenthood health center on Florida’s Gulf Coast, new restrictions on who can get an abortion are shaking up routines and creating challenges for the clinic’s patients, doctors and nurses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bittel
title: A Giant Stingray May Be the World’s Largest Freshwater Fish
description: In the Mekong River in Cambodia, fishers and researchers found a 13-foot-long, 661-pound stingray — a win for conservation efforts in the area.
content: For 17 years, Zeb Hogan, a biologist, has been searching for the world’s largest freshwater fish. On June 13, his team found it — a giant freshwater stingray, or Urogymnus polylepis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Israel’s Governing Coalition Collapses
description: Also, forced labor is found in China’s battery supply and Colombia elects a new president.
content: Israel’s governing coalition will vote to dissolve Parliament before the end of the month, the prime minister’s office said, sending the country into its fifth election in three years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carly Olson
title: Ukraine bans some Russian music and books.
description: The Ukrainian Parliament voted to ban some Russian media and sent two bills to President Zelensky to sign.
content: Ukraine’s Parliament voted to ban the distribution of Russian books and the playing or performance of Russian music by post-Soviet-era artists, the latest display of Kyiv fiercely distancing itself from Russian culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Matthew Cullen
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Russia’s brutal campaign to capture Sievierodonetsk.
content: Russian forces mounted an assault on Sunday against Toshkivka, a key Ukrainian defensive position near Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk. The fight highlighted Ukraine’s faltering defense of two of the last cities in Luhansk Province of the Donbas region that are not yet under Russian control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Faludi
title: Feminism Made a Faustian Bargain With Celebrity Culture. Now It’s Paying the Price.
description: How did modern feminism lose Roe v. Wade? An answer lies in Depp v. Heard.
content: One month almost to the day after Americans learned of Supreme Court Justice Samuel Alito’s draft opinion that would eviscerate the constitutional right of women to control their bodies and so their lives, millions sat glued to their screens to witness the verdict in the Johnny Depp-Amber Heard defamation trial, in which the jury awarded more than $10 million to Mr. Depp. In a statement afterward, Ms. Heard said she was “disappointed with what this verdict means for women.” “It sets back the clock,” she said, “to a time when a woman who spoke up and spoke out could be publicly shamed and humiliated.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: The Mystery of Fleet Street: An Article on Boris Johnson Vanishes
description: What happened to a story published in The Times of London that was critical of Prime Minister Boris Johnson? The disappearance has London’s media world guessing.
content: LONDON — The most talked-about article in the British newspapers last weekend was one that featured juicy allegations of love, ambition and thwarted corruption at the pinnacle of the British government. Then it vanished abruptly from the pages of The Times of London in the early hours of Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: How Real-Life and Fictional Horror Seeped Into ‘The Black Phone’
description: Influenced by “Rosemary’s Baby” and “The Devil’s Backbone,” the filmmaker wove details from his childhood into this supernatural movie starring Ethan Hawke.
content: After scoring a hit with the Marvel movie “Doctor Strange” in 2016, the director Scott Derrickson started working on its sequel, “Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness.” In January 2020, however, he abruptly left that movie because of creative differences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim, Patrick Kingsley, Christiaan Triebert, Hiba Yazbek and Phil Robibero
title: The Killing of Shireen Abu Akleh: Tracing a Bullet to an Israeli Convoy
description: A New York Times investigation found that the bullet that killed a Palestinian-American journalist was fired from the approximate position of an Israeli military vehicle.
content: JENIN, West Bank — The journalists thought they were safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
title: Israel’s Government Collapses, Setting Up 5th Election in 3 Years
description: The governing coalition decided to dissolve Parliament, plunging the country back into paralysis and throwing a political lifeline to Benjamin Netanyahu.
content: JERUSALEM — Israel’s governing coalition will dissolve Parliament before the end of the month, bringing down the government and sending the country to a fifth election in three years, the prime minister said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi, Constant Méheut and Aurelien Breeden
title: A Fragmented Parliament Brings Macron Back Down to Earth
description: President Emmanuel Macron largely sidelined Parliament during his first term. But now he has lost his absolute majority in the lower house, forcing him to seek compromise with a reinvigorated opposition.
content: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron earned the nickname Jupiter in his first term for his top-down governing style, using the full powers of France’s executive branch and largely ignoring Parliament.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: June 20, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 20, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grayson Haver Currin
title: Joan Shelley’s New Songs Soothe Old Wounds
description: As a Kentucky farm kid, the singer and songwriter made music to have a voice in her troubled home. On her new album, “The Spur,” her songs finally process those times.
content: SKYLIGHT, Ky. — The second week of November 2016: Donald Trump was president-elect, and Leonard Cohen was dead. The songwriter Joan Shelley and the guitarist Nathan Salsburg — her collaborator for the better part of a decade and boyfriend for the better part of a year — were the opening act on a tour that suddenly seemed meaningless. They listened to Cohen’s haunted farewell, “You Want It Darker,” on repeat and bickered about the news.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Gun Proposals Rely on a Vast, Flawed System
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 20, 2022.
content: “It’s like going to the airport and being told that some people have to go through security and some don’t.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong, Ali Watkins and Colin Moynihan
title: Taxi Jumps Curb, Critically Injuring 3 People in Manhattan
description: The accident happened in the Flatiron district, a neighborhood packed with hotels, bars and restaurants.
content: Three people were in critical condition on Monday afternoon after a taxi jumped the sidewalk in Manhattan’s Flatiron district. The driver hit a cyclist and several pedestrians with his vehicle, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley and Lananh Nguyen
title: When Customers Say Their Money Was Stolen on Zelle, Banks Often Refuse to Pay
description: Federal law requires banks to reimburse customers for unauthorized electronic transfers, but they often refuse, stranding victims.
content: Argelys Oriach was on his way home from a shopping trip one evening in March when he was robbed at gunpoint. The thief demanded his iPhone and passcode. Mr. Oriach turned them over and fled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
title: Israel Confirms Regional Military Project, Showing Its Growing Role
description: The Israeli defense minister, Benny Gantz, said Israel was working with other countries in the Middle East to combat Iranian military threats.
content: JERUSALEM — The Israeli government confirmed on Monday that it is part of a regional military partnership to combat threats from Iran, in the latest example of Israel’s growing engagement with some Arab governments and the recalibration of Middle Eastern alliances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Despite Another Covid Surge, Deaths Stay Near Lows
description: Most Americans now carry some immune protection, experts said, whether from vaccines, infection or both.
content: For two years, the coronavirus killed Americans on a brutal, predictable schedule: A few weeks after infections climbed so did deaths, cutting an unforgiving path across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Lennie Rosenbluth, Who Led North Carolina to a Title, Dies at 89
description: With a starting lineup of New Yorkers, the undefeated Tarheels beat a Kansas team led by Wilt Chamberlain in triple overtime to win the 1957 N.C.A.A. championship.
content: Lennie Rosenbluth, the All-America forward who led a North Carolina team with a starting lineup of New Yorkers to an unbeaten season and a thrilling victory over Wilt Chamberlain’s Kansas squad in the 1957 N.C.A.A. basketball tournament championship game, died on Saturday. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Thomas
title: A Herd in Exile: Riding Horses on Mozambique’s Bazaruto Archipelago
description: A photographer spent a few weeks helping run a horseback riding program on the white-sand beaches of Benguerra Island. Here’s what she saw.
content: With a map in one hand and a cold beer in the other, I sat alone at the bar of the Baobab Beach Backpackers Lodge in the coastal town of Vilankulo, gazing out at the sweeping sandbars and vivid turquoise waters that surround Mozambique’s Bazaruto Archipelago. I’d planned to leave the following morning for Zimbabwe, and I was chatting with the bartender about the logistics of my trip. Then, suddenly, a car’s headlights lit up the bar, and I saw a familiar face heading toward me. I had a feeling my plans were about to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: ‘Hooded; or Being Black for Dummies’ Review: A Tragic Pageantry
description: Tearrance Arvelle Chisholm’s ambitious and sometimes metaphysical comedy playfully tries to tackle thorny issues at 59E59 Theaters.
content: What defines Blackness? The idea that there might be a clear answer is absurd. But skin color is all it takes to land two diametrically opposed teenagers in the same jail cell. In the eyes of the law, at least, the connotations of race are obvious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: Google Says It’s Time for Longtime Small-Business Users to Pay Up
description: Google is charging some small businesses for email and other apps after more than a decade of free use. Business owners say Google is being callous.
content: When Google told some small businesses in January that they would no longer be able to use a customized email service and other workplace apps for free, it felt like a broken promise for Richard J. Dalton Jr., a longtime user who operates a scholastic test-prep company in Vancouver, British Columbia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: BTS’s ‘Proof’ Opens at No. 1 as the K-Pop Powerhouse Takes a Break
description: The boy band’s new compilation marks its sixth time atop the Billboard 200 chart. The group’s seven members will focus on solo projects.
content: On June 10, the K-pop powerhouse BTS released a three-disc compilation album, “Proof.” It was sure to be a hit, and this week it opens at No. 1 on the Billboard 200 album chart, with the equivalent of 314,000 sales in the United States, according to the tracking service Luminate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Goldsmith
title: Prosecute Trump? Put Yourself in Merrick Garland’s Shoes.
description: The attorney general will have to make three decisions, each more difficult than the previous, and none of which has an obvious answer.
content: The evidence gathered by the Jan. 6 committee and in some of the federal cases against those involved in the Capitol attack pose for Attorney General Merrick Garland one of the most consequential questions that any attorney general has ever faced: Should the United States indict former President Donald Trump?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton DiSclafani
title: Pregnancy, Guns and Politics in Alabama
description: Republicans and Democrats both seem to forget they represent people like me too.
content: AUBURN, Ala. — I’m a left-leaning Democrat, but on May 24, I voted on the Republican ballot in Alabama’s primary election. The state’s primaries are open, which means Democrats can request a Republican ballot, and vice versa. Alabama is a deep red state, and I wanted some say in electing the officials who will represent me, because they will almost all certainly be Republican.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: In N.H.L. Finals, Avalanche Go From Chaser to Front-Runner
description: In taking a 2-0 series lead against the two-time defending champion Tampa Bay Lightning in the Stanley Cup finals, Colorado’s complete ascension to the top of the league is within reach.
content: DENVER — Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals was described as the challenger catching up to the reigning champion. In Game 2, the challenger flew right on past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah and David Montgomery
title: Texas Republicans Approve Far-Right Platform Declaring Biden’s Election Illegitimate
description: The platform, which was voted on at the Republican state party convention in Houston, was the latest sign of Texas conservatives moving further to the right.
content: The Republican Party in Texas made a series of far-right declarations as part of its official party platform over the weekend, claiming that President Biden was not legitimately elected, issuing a “rebuke” to Senator John Cornyn for his work on bipartisan gun legislation and referring to homosexuality as “an abnormal lifestyle choice.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Jan. 6 Hearing Will Highlight Trump’s Pressure Campaign on State Officials
description: The House committee investigating the Capitol attack will also underscore the vitriol and suffering that election workers endured because of President Donald J. Trump’s lies.
content: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol on Tuesday plans to detail President Donald J. Trump’s personal involvement in a pressure campaign on state officials to subvert the will of the voters as well as an audacious scheme to put forward false slates of electors in seven states to keep him in power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Reid J. Epstein
title: Pence Navigates a Possible White House Run, and a Fraught Political Moment
description: In a speech on Monday, former Vice President Mike Pence sounded like a future presidential candidate, but not like someone interested in discussing the specifics of Jan. 6.
content: Former Vice President Mike Pence has emerged from the Jan. 6 hearings in a peculiar position.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley, Lauren Herstik and Douglas Morino
title: Jury in Bill Cosby’s Sex Assault Case Ends Third Day of Deliberation
description: No verdict has been reached in the civil case brought by a woman who says Mr. Cosby molested her at the Playboy Mansion in 1975, when she was 16.
content: The jury in the Bill Cosby sexual assault trial deliberated for a third day Monday without reaching a verdict even though the judge in the case indicated at the end of deliberations last week that the jurors were close to deciding the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: The Kremlin says two captured American fighters are ‘soldiers of fortune’ not protected by the rules of war.
description: Moscow says the Americans who fought for Ukraine are not regular soldiers who would be covered by the Geneva Conventions, calling their conduct criminal.
content: The Kremlin’s chief spokesman told NBC News on Monday that two American fighters who went missing in Ukraine, Alex Drueke, 39, and Andy Tai Ngoc Huynh, 27, were “soldiers of fortune,” and had been taken into custody. The spokesman also claimed that the two men were not protected by the Geneva Conventions as prisoners of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: The Supreme Court, Public Opinion and the Fate of Roe
description: According to the conventional wisdom, the court rarely strays too far from the popular will. That view will face a reckoning in the coming weeks.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court, it has long been said, seldom gets very far out of step with public opinion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Mike Pence Was of Two Minds
description: The man who stood up to Trump is the man who didn’t stand up to Trump.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, I never did like Mike Pence at all — his far-right social values would have turned me off even if he didn’t call his wife “Mother.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: In a Return to the Land, Tribes Will Jointly Manage a National Monument
description: Five Native American tribes will work with the Bureau of Land Management to plan and conserve Bears Ears National Monument in Utah, officials said.
content: Bears Ears National Monument, whose red-rock landscape sprawls across more than 1.3 million acres in southeastern Utah, will be managed jointly by the federal government and Native American tribes in what administration officials said represents a “one-of-a-kind” model of cooperation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter May
title: Will Zalatoris, Three-Time Major Runner-Up, Is Getting Impatient
description: Zalatoris came close to sending the U.S. Open to a playoff on Sunday, only to finish disappointed once again. “We’re talking inches,” he says.
content: BROOKLINE, Mass. — As his putt approached the hole on the 18th green on Sunday evening, Will Zalatoris thought he was headed to a thrilling playoff that would determine the U.S. Open champion. All the ball had to do was drop and Zalatoris and Matt Fitzpatrick would settle things in a two-hole playoff.
source.name: The New York Times

title: $2.9 Million Homes in California
description: A modern farmhouse in Los Angeles, a Spanish-style home in Kensington and a midcentury-modern retreat in Palm Springs.
content: A modern farmhouse in Los Angeles, a Spanish-style home in Kensington and a midcentury-modern retreat in Palm Springs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Ostrovsky, Ainara Tiefenthäler and Alessandro Pavone
title: Surviving Russia’s ‘Filtration Camps’
description: Thousands of refugees from Ukraine have been sent to so-called filtration camps, where they have been interrogated and then forced to resettle to Russia. Some Ukrainians escaped to Estonia. They told us their stories.
content: Thousands of refugees from Ukraine have been sent to so-called filtration camps, where they have been interrogated and then forced to resettle to Russia. Some Ukrainians escaped to Estonia. They told us their stories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Take the time for a rewarding crispy fried tofu sandwich, made either on the stovetop or in the oven.
content: Good morning. It’s difficult to imagine a more delicious thing to eat on a Monday night in the second half of June than a crispy fried tofu sandwich (above).
source.name: The New York Times

title: Parents Fearing for Their Children’s Lives
description: Parents express fears for their children in a time of mass shootings. Also: The gun bill; famine in East Africa; the irreligious right; college debt.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
